newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Saudi, Kuwait to raise Neutral Zone onshore output.
newsitem.headline: Saudi, Kuwait to raise Neutral Zone onshore output.

text.p: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and Saudi Arabian Texaco have agreed to spend $400 million to raise onshore output in the Neutral Zone to 300,000 barrels per day (bpd), Kuwaiti officials were quoted as saying on Thursday.

They said production was expected to reach 300,000 bpd by 1998 from the current 190,000-200,000 bpd which is equally shared by the two states and jointly operated by Texaco and state-owned Kuwait Oil Company.
Kuwaiti newspapers also quoted Texaco officials as saying the U.S. firm would contribute $100 million to the cost of the development project.
It said the officials were speaking at a ceremony by Saudi Texaco, a wholly owned Texaco Inc subsidiary, marking 60 years of ties between the kingdom and Texaco.
Japan's Arabian Oil Co Ltd operates offshore fields in the zone and plans to raise output to 350,000 bpd by the end of the century from 315,000 bpd.
A majority of AOC stock is held by Japanese interests but Kuwait and Saudi Arabia each hold 10 percent.
Kuwait and Riyadh have equally shared mineral rights in the zone since its establishment in 1922 by the sultanate of Nejd, now part of Saudi Arabia, and Kuwait, then a British protectorate.
